welcome.title: Welcome to the Movement to Onomatopoeia Study
welcome.introduction: Thank you for agreeing to participate in this survey. As a dancer or a movement practitioner we consider you an expert and it is in this capacity that we would like you to help our research on movement onomatopoeia in Japanese. Onomatopoeia are sounds such as XXXX or YYYY that, while not being officially a word in Japanese, can convey meaning (animal sound, feeling, sensation, movement, shape, textureâ€¦) through the quality of the sound itself.
welcome.description: We will be presenting you short animations (based on movement capture of actual persons). Each animation depicts an expressive whole body movement.

instructions.title: What you'll do:
steps: Upon a second viewing, come up with an onomatopoeia that you feel, intuitively, that fits the animated motion sequence or a part of it.
Write down the onomatopoeia and mark the time when it occurs (it could correspond to the entire sequence as well).
You can describe multiple moments in each video if you want

additional_info.no_onomatopoeia: It is also possible that some of the animated sequences do not evoke any onomatopeia for you. This is fine too. You can watch and re-watch the video as many times as necessary before passing to the next one.
additional_info.about_onomatopoeia: Regarding the onomatopeia: some onomatopeia in Japanese have a very specific and established meaning (for example: XXXX means for many people YYYY). This will most probably not be the case in these videos. What we ask you to do is to freely associate these sequences with onomatopeia (it doesn't matter if the chosen onomatopoeia has already an established meaning in a different context).
additional_info.intuition_emphasis: Please follow your own intuition! There is no right or wrong answer!

form.movement_practice_placeholder: e.g., dance, somatics, manual therapy, movement analysis...

tutorial.title: Tutorial - Learning the Survey
tutorial.welcome_text: This tutorial will guide you through the survey interface step by step. You'll learn how to watch videos, input onomatopoeia descriptions, and navigate the system. Let's get started!
tutorial.completion_text: Great job! You've learned how to use the survey interface. Now you're ready to start the real survey and help us collect onomatopoeia descriptions.
tutorial.saved_locally: Tutorial data saved locally (not sent to server)
tutorial.all_videos_complete: You have reached the end of all videos in the tutorial.
tutorial.step1_text: You can change the language of the interface using this dropdown menu. The survey is available in English and Japanese.
tutorial.step1_instruction: Click on 'Next' to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step2_text: This is the video player. You can play, pause, and control the video using the controls. You can also click the video directly to play / pause it.
tutorial.step2_instruction: Click on the video to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step3_text: You can click and drag on the video timeline to move to specific moments in the video.
tutorial.step3_instruction: Try dragging the timeline to move through the video.
tutorial.step4_title: Did you think of an Onomatopoeia?
tutorial.step4_text: When you see something that makes you think of an onomatopoeia, you'll need to respond 'Yes' here. If you didn't think of any onomatopoeia, you can click 'No' to skip to the next video.
tutorial.step4_instruction: Click the highlighted 'Yes' button to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step5_text: After clicking 'Yes', a form appear to enter the onomatopoeia information. Write here the onomatopoeia you thought of in the video.
tutorial.step5_instruction: Type something to be able to continue the tutorial, then click the 'Next' button.
tutorial.step6_text: Position the video at the moment when the onomatopoeia begins. Then click on the 'Get Starting Time' button to record the start time.
tutorial.step6_instruction: Click on the highlighted button to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step7_text: Position the video at the moment when the onomatopoeia ends. Then click on the 'Get Ending Time' button to record the end time.
tutorial.step7_instruction: Click on the highlighted button to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step8_text: You can optionally record yourself pronouncing the onomatopoeia. This helps us understand how you would say the sound. This step is optional in the survey.
tutorial.step8_instruction: Click on 'Next' to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step9_text: Once you've filled in the details, use this button to save your onomatopoeia description. Note: what you enter during this tutorial will not be saved to the server.
tutorial.step9_instruction: Click the 'Save Onomatopoeia' button to continue the tutorial.
tutorial.step10_text: The video buttons change color to show your progress: Grey = not yet completed. Green = you've saved at least one onomatopoeia. Blue = the current video you're watching. Yellow = you've indicated the video has no onomatopoeia.
tutorial.step10_instruction: You've completed the tutorial! Click 'Complete Tutorial' when ready.
